Introduction to dfsummary

Source: vignettes/dfsummary.Rmd
dfsummary.Rmd
library(dfsummary)
library(data.table)

Introduction

Creating descriptive summaries of variables in data.frames are a common task. In the context of summarizing patient characteristics of a population, individual level data is often person-sensitive and proper precautions have to be made to be sure that the summarized data can not be used to identify data on individuals. The main aim of dfsummary is to provide functions for summarizing data and automatically mask any descriptive summary statistics that are deemed person-sensitive. A secondary aim of dfsummary is to keep things simple: the package depends only on data.table (which only depends on R itself) and the summarized data is returned in a data.frame.

Summarize a data.frame

To illustrate how the package works, we will use a simple simulated dataset imitating a population with information on an exposure variable, and different types of patient characteristics.

set.seed(1)
n <- 20
pop <-data.frame(
  exposure = sample(c("no", "yes"), n, replace = TRUE),
  cat_var = sample(c("A", "B", "C"), n, replace = TRUE),
  bin_var = sample(c(0, 1), n, replace = TRUE),
  cont_var = rnorm(n)
)

pop
#>    exposure cat_var bin_var    cont_var
#> 1        no       A       0 -0.10278773
#> 2       yes       C       1  0.38767161
#> 3        no       A       1 -0.05380504
#> 4        no       A       1 -1.37705956
#> 5       yes       A       1 -0.41499456
#> 6        no       A       1 -0.39428995
#> 7        no       B       0 -0.05931340
#> 8        no       A       0  1.10002537
#> 9       yes       A       1  0.76317575
#> 10      yes       B       0 -0.16452360
#> 11       no       B       1 -0.25336168
#> 12       no       B       1  0.69696338
#> 13       no       A       0  0.55666320
#> 14       no       C       0 -0.68875569
#> 15       no       A       1 -0.70749516
#> 16      yes       C       1  0.36458196
#> 17      yes       B       1  0.76853292
#> 18      yes       B       0 -0.11234621
#> 19      yes       B       0  0.88110773
#> 20       no       B       1  0.39810588

Now lets summarize the data using the tbl_summary function from the package.

summarized_pop <- tbl_summary(
  x = pop,
  vars = c("cat_var", "bin_var", "cont_var"),
  by = "exposure"
)

summarized_pop
#>      .by .var_name .var_type .var_level    .stat_label     .stat_value
#>  1: .all        .n         n                         n              20
#>  2: .all   bin_var       bin                     n_pct      12 (60.0%)
#>  3: .all   cat_var       cat          A          n_pct       9 (45.0%)
#>  4: .all   cat_var       cat          B          n_pct       8 (40.0%)
#>  5: .all   cat_var       cat          C          n_pct       3 (15.0%)
#>  6: .all  cont_var      cont            median_p25_p75  0.1 (-0.3;0.6)
#>  7:   no        .n         n                         n              12
#>  8:   no   bin_var       bin                     n_pct       7 (58.3%)
#>  9:   no   cat_var       cat          A          n_pct       7 (58.3%)
#> 10:   no   cat_var       cat          B          n_pct       4 (33.3%)
#> 11:   no   cat_var       cat          C          n_pct        1 (8.3%)
#> 12:   no  cont_var      cont            median_p25_p75 -0.1 (-0.5;0.4)
#> 13:  yes        .n         n                         n               8
#> 14:  yes   bin_var       bin                     n_pct       5 (62.5%)
#> 15:  yes   cat_var       cat          A          n_pct       2 (25.0%)
#> 16:  yes   cat_var       cat          B          n_pct       4 (50.0%)
#> 17:  yes   cat_var       cat          C          n_pct       2 (25.0%)
#> 18:  yes  cont_var      cont            median_p25_p75  0.3 (-0.1;0.7)

By design, the summarized data is in long format. It is up to the user to make the aggregated data look more presentable. Lets start by restructuring the data to a wider format, with a column for each exposure level.

wide_dat <- dcast(
  summarized_pop,
  .var_name + .var_level ~ .by,
  value.var = ".stat_value"
)

wide_dat
#>    .var_name .var_level           .all              no            yes
#> 1:        .n                        20              12              8
#> 2:   bin_var                12 (60.0%)       7 (58.3%)      5 (62.5%)
#> 3:   cat_var          A      9 (45.0%)       7 (58.3%)      2 (25.0%)
#> 4:   cat_var          B      8 (40.0%)       4 (33.3%)      4 (50.0%)
#> 5:   cat_var          C      3 (15.0%)        1 (8.3%)      2 (25.0%)
#> 6:  cont_var            0.1 (-0.3;0.6) -0.1 (-0.5;0.4) 0.3 (-0.1;0.7)

Illustrate masking

We can see that the summarized data contains aggregated counts larger than zero and smaller than five; values often considered person-sensitive. Person-sensitive counts can be automatically masked using the mask argument.

pop |>
  tbl_summary(
    vars = c("cat_var", "bin_var", "cont_var"),
    by = "exposure",
    mask = TRUE
  ) |>
  dcast(
    .var_name + .var_level ~ .by,
    value.var = ".stat_value"
  ) 
#>    .var_name .var_level           .all              no            yes
#> 1:        .n                        20              12              8
#> 2:   bin_var                12 (60.0%)       7 (58.3%)      5 (62.5%)
#> 3:   cat_var          A      9 (45.0%)               *              *
#> 4:   cat_var          B              *               *              *
#> 5:   cat_var          C              *               *              *
#> 6:  cont_var            0.1 (-0.3;0.6) -0.1 (-0.5;0.4) 0.3 (-0.1;0.7)

We can see that quite a lot has beene masked. Why? See “masking” vignette for more information?

Finalize table for publication using gt

Finalize table for publication using flextable
